_exec_summary.SummaryText:
June 22, 2009

Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company 
Tulsa, Oklahoma
    
RMP Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies


Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company Environmental Policy Statement
The Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company (STRC) is strongly committed to legal compliance, environmental stewardship and the continuous improvement of its environmental compliance.  To that end, we have developed this Environmental policy Statement to identify our vision and objectives.  All activities at the company must reflect this vision and further these objectives.

Vision:
  Minimize our impact on the environment while competitively producing high-quality refinery products.

Objectives:
* Foster a culture of environmental responsibility and commitment among employees and management.
* Continually drive down the environmental impact of our operations through the efficient use of energy, waste minimization, and reducing discharges to the air and water.
* Achieve excellence in the performance of our environmental responsibilities through employee education and compliance with all applicable environmental laws, regulations and other environmental initiatives to which the company subscribes.
* Encourage employees to communicate to management any issues of environmental concern and require management to respond promptly to such concerns.
* Regularly communicate and work with our outside stakeholders (e.g., customers, neighbors, government officials, and regulatory agencies) to enhance our environmetal performance.


Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company Health and Safety Policy
Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company is committed to provide petroleum products and hospitality services in a safe and responsible manner. We recognize that excellence in managing health and safety issues is critical to the welfare of our employees and to the long-term success of our business. This policy requires full compliance with all laws and regulations and establishes principles and guide

lines that serve as the foundation for our commitment to our employees and customers.
 
Sinclair commits to:

* Ensure every employee understands that they are expected to perform work in a safe and prudent manner, and will be accountable for their personal actions and safe behavior. No one is ever expected to perform an unsafe task.

* Incorporate health and safety concerns as an integral part of our business and a part of our strategic and operational decision making criteria.

* Establish, upgrade and audit company standards and procedures that will ensure all current health and safety regulatory requirements are met.

* Eliminate injuries, occupational illness and property damage by insisting on safe equipment operation, compliance with standard procedures, employee training and safe behavior.

* Provide the leadership, resources and motivation necessary to maintain effective health and safety systems. Supervisors will be accountable for the human and physical resources under their control.

* Maintain emergency response procedures and trained personnel to minimize the effects of spills, accidental releases, fires or other emergencies. 

* Foster a professional relationship with local, state and federal agencies.


Corporate Philosophy for Process Safety Management 
STRC will work proactively to provide a safe workplace for each employee and continue to promote safety practices among employees for their health and welfare.  This will be accomplished at all facilities by actively assuring wide employee participation in a thorough Process Safety Management program (PSM) and complete safety training.

The PSM program will be managed by a corporate team, but completed on a facility basis under the specific direction of the facility manager.  The program will conform to OSHA regulations contained in 29 CFR Part 1910.  STRC has devoted the leadership, manpower, and capital investment necessary to complete the program.

STRC will update the Safety Management Program ev

ery three years through the PSM audit.  Emphasis will be placed on managing the higher risk areas of our facilities first, the priority of which will be established by each facility team.


Statement of the Sinclair Tulsa Refinery
The Management of STRC recognizes and firmly believes in the need for a safe environment for both the refinery and the local community.  Our policy is to ensure that our efforts with prevention-through planning, training, reasonable process controls, timely maintenance, and communication with our neighbors-will help us prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  If a release does occur, however, our trained personnel, in conjunction with trained personnel from the community, will respond to control and mitigate the release.


Definition of Processes and Regulated Substances
STRC operates a variety of petroleum refining process to produce propane, propylene, butanes, butylene, gasolines, kerosene, diesel fuels and asphalt.  These processes include: atmospheric and vacuum distillation, hydrotreating, reforming, fluidized catalytic cracking, alkylation, and associated supporting operations such as crude unloading, sulfur recovery, product blending, storage and product loading.  The NAICS code for STRC is 32411 and must meet the requirements of Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program Level 3.

The RMP rule defines a process as "Any activity involving a regulated substance, including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or on-site movement of such substances, or combination of these activities.  For the purposes of this definition, any group of vessels that are interconnected, or separate vessels that are located such that a regulated substance could be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process" (re: 40 CFR 68.3).

Per the RMP definition, STRC has the following RMP regulated flammables in its processes:

* Hydrogen
* Pentane
* Butane
* Isobutane
* Butene
* Propane
* Propene
* Ethane
* Ethylene
* Methane

These substances are not known to exist at the refinery in pure form but rather as components in flammable mixtures potentially meeting the RMP threshold quantity level for flammables.

STRC also has the following regulated toxics in its processes:

* Hydrogen Sulfide
* Sulfur Dioxide
* Sulfur Trioxide
* Hydrogen Chloride
* Carbon Disulfide
* Anhydrous Ammonia


The maximum on site quantities of these regulated toxics do not meet RMP threshold levels.  However, STRC have prevention and safety programs in place for all Hydrogen Sulfide handling units as part of our PSM Program. 

The handling of all RMP flammable and toxic substances, regardless of quantity on-site, is performed in a manner consistent with the RMP general duty clause.  

Based upon threshold quantities and process definition, STRC is reporting the following processes in its RMP:

-    The Butane Spheres:    A flammable mixture containing primarily isobutane, butane, 1-butene, propane, pentane, isopentane, 1-pentene and propylene.  The maximum quantity of this flammable mixture onsite at any time is estimated to be 14,000,000 pounds.  This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the flammable mixture with an allowance for process piping volume.

-    The Propane Bullets:    The maximum quantity of this flammable mixture onsite at any time is 1,800,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the flammable mixture with an allowance for process piping volume.

-    The Alkylation Unit (Alky Unit): The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 6,300,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    The Crude Distillation Unit (CDU): The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 1,900,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    T

he Diesel Hydrotreating Unit (DHTU): The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 1,100,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    The Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit (FCCU): The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 1,300,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    The SCANFINER Unit: The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 85,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    The PENEX/UNIFINER Unit (PENEX): The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 340,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    The Poly Unit: The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 170,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    The Naphtha Hydro-DeSulfulrization Unit (NHDS): The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 330,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.

-    The Continuous Catalytic Reforming Unit (CCR): The maximum quantity of the flammable mixture onsite at any time is 68,000 pounds. This estimate is based upon the total storage capacity of the mixture with an allowance for process piping volume and material in process.


Hazard Assessment Results
STRC does not have toxic substances onsite that meet the threshold requirements for RMP coverage.  However, we are tracking hydrogen sulfide internal

ly to ensure that our prevention and safety programs adequately cover potential releases. 


5-Year Accident History
STRC had three RMP-defined accidents in the last five years. While releases have been documented, none of these releases had offsite consequences. After each release, STRC investigated what happened, recorded the recommendations, and made changes to our processes, procedures, or safety systems to mitigate and eliminate future problems. 


Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
STRC has instituted and maintains a process safety management (PSM) program for preventing or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable or explosive chemicals.  While the following sections are required and practiced for PSM, STRC has other programs and practices (i.e. lock out/tag out, etc.) which add to the operational safety of the refinery.

Employees participate in all aspects of PSM by being members of the process hazard analysis team for new installations or procedures, members of the prestartup safety review team and being a member of incident investigations.  Employees participate in development and review of operating procedures and by suggesting and becoming knowledgeable of changes in their respective areas of responsibilities (management of change).  Process safety information, Material Safety Data Sheets and mechanical equipment data is available to all employees.  Employees are trained and refreshed on the use of hot work permits (as well as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment, line opening and blinding, control of entrance/exit of units, Hazmat and emergency response, etc.).

Process safety information is provided in many forms.  A hazards communication program and laboratory chemical hygiene plan informs employees and contractors of the chemical hazards to which they may be exposed and the measures that need to be taken to protect them.  The engineering recor

ds and operating manuals provide maximum intended inventories, safe upper and lower operating limits, evaluation of consequences of deviation, materials of construction, piping and instrumentation diagrams, electrical area classifications, relief systems design and design basis, ventilation systems, design codes and standards, energy and material balances, and safety systems.

Process hazards analysis has been performed on all applicable processes primarily by the hazard and operability study method.  This structured approach uses process parameters such as flow, temperature, pressure, etc. to examine impact of deviations.  These analyses produce recommendations for controls or changes.  New facilities are subjected to this analysis before operation.

Written operating procedures are in place to provide clear instruction for all aspects of operations of the refinery.  These procedures cover any type of operation on each unit, including anything from normal operation to startup procedures to emergency shutdown to partial operation of a unit.

Training is provided to all operations employees covering their job functions working on the process units.  Initial training requires a program of classroom and on-the-job training which takes a four-step progression of levels of certification.  A written and/or performance test is given at completion of the four levels and progression to the next level cannot take place without the approval of the supervisor and the Operations Manager.  Beyond the initial training, refresher training is continually provided which allows recertification of all operators every three years.

Contractor's safety is monitored. When performing maintenance and repair, turnaround, major renovation or specialty work on or adjacent to a process unit contractors are required to have a safe work plan per STRC?s Contractor Safety Management Program.  STRC evaluates each contractor's safety performance.  Each contractor must provide safety policies and prog

rams, injury and illness performance reports and training records before performing work.  Safety orientation is provided before starting work to inform contractor's employees of all the safety programs practices which must be followed inside the refinery.

Before starting up any new unit or significantly modified unit, a pre-startup safety review is held.  This constitutes a final checklist for the process prior to startup.  The review ensures that all safety considerations have been built and are operable before the unit actually starts. 


Emergency Response Program
STRC has written an Emergency Response Plan to set in action if an emergency takes place.  The refinery has its own Emergency Response Team that can respond to any Fire, Rescue, Spill or Vapor Release.  The Emergency Response Team receives specialized training enabling them to handle industrial type emergencies.  The Emergency Response Team can respond 24 hours a day in the event of an emergency.  If an emergency should occur the Refinery operates under the Incident Command type system along with having its own 800 MHZ two-way radio that is programmed to the Local Emeregency Planning Committee (e.g. Fire Department) radio frequency.  With these two items in place the refinery can establish quick communication with the Fire Department for aid and public notification if the emergency warrants.  In addition the Fire Department is given periodic walk through tours of the refinery to familiarize themselves with the specific areas of the plant along with reviewing the different types of emergency equipment the refinery has and its location.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety
STRC has instituted the following items to improve safety for its employees and community:
* Removed chlorine from its water treating system and replaced it with a much safer substitute.
* Installed excessive vibration monitors and emergency shutdowns on critical process unit pumps.
* Purchased a Pierce Foam pumper Industrial Fire Truc

k.
* Conducted a facility siting study to locate occupied temporary and permanent buildings in safe areas.


Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company 
Tulsa, Oklahoma
